name: NPR
text:
California has activated its "mass fatality" program as the state continues to set new coronavirus records.

Gov. Newsom says 60 refrigerated units are available, and 5,000 body bags have been sent to some of the hardest-hit counties. https://t.co/ukhLwHCZVY

name: NPR
text:
Cleavon Gilman is an ER physician in an Arizona county where about half of hospital beds are occupied by COVID-19 patients.

"Health care providers are walking into a war zone every day," he says. "The amount of emotional strain ... is just unimaginable." https://t.co/b1MzVvOKSo

name: NPR
text:
Cedric Richmond — President-elect Joe Biden's pick for director of the Office of Public Engagement — has tested positive for the coronavirus. 

He was not in close contact with Biden, says Biden's spokeswoman.
https://t.co/E5qNo45c3y

name: NPR
text:
"Don't think of the vaccine as a light switch — that the minute it starts going into people's arms, normalcy resumes. ... It's going to take awhile for things to get under control," Atlantic writer @edyong209 says.
https://t.co/PGWn9hSefN

name: NPR
text:
"My theory is that they had wanted me out for a while because I spoke up a lot about issues related to black people, women and marginalization," says Timnit Gebru, a renowned Black researcher who was ousted from Google.
https://t.co/gA0oB7psNI

name: NPR
text:
Southern California has run out of ICU beds for coronavirus patients. There are fewer than 100 beds available in L.A. County. (@LAist)
https://t.co/OzT7q4n3b3

name: NPR
text:
A Texas executive was sentenced to 20 years in prison for running a scheme in which thousands of patients with long-term illnesses were falsely told they had just 6 months to live — and were then sold hospice care.

Some were kept in hospice for years.
https://t.co/gjwHkLvnE5

name: NPR
text: RT @jazznight: 2020 was a year of heavy loss for the jazz community. In our annual In Memoriam radio special, we remember and honor 10 musicians through stories and music. https://t.co/Rb4HGOJSw5

name: NPR
text:
"It's as if you wake up one morning and suddenly realize that a burglar has been going in and out of your house for the last six months," said a former general counsel to the NSA.

Here's what we know about the massive cyberattack on government networks:
https://t.co/LT2KdtqG3C

name: NPR
text:
We're tracking how the virus is impacting individual members of Congress. Here's the latest.
https://t.co/rUWPIsiew3

name: NPR
text:
The Trump administration says two new rules rolling back water efficiency standards on appliances like showerheads are a victory for Americans' "quality of life."

Environmental advocates say they'll waste water and drive up utility bills.
https://t.co/o89ZrfZz1I

name: NPR
text:
About 68,000 vaccine doses will initially be distributed among hard-hit Indigenous communities in the U.S. Native Americans are 4 times as likely to be hospitalized with COVID-19.
https://t.co/aZqlzeEKHj

name: NPR
text:
We're tracking President-elect Joe Biden's cabinet nominees and advisers. Here's a look at how the administration is shaping up so far.
https://t.co/Nk9ocf4YA0

name: NPR
text:
A new study of toddlers in Kenya suggests that having an older sister can have a powerful impact on a child's development — leading to improved early vocabulary and fine motor skills.
https://t.co/0W9BpbxSFp

name: NPR
text:
Several colleagues of ousted Black researcher Timnit Gebru have written a letter to Google CEO Sundar Pichai asking that she be reinstated and calling for "swift and structural changes if this work is to continue."
https://t.co/Ww6vfkTcD4

name: NPR
text:
Thanks to archivists and audio detectives, it's now possible to trace John Coltrane's "Giant Steps" session in microscopic detail, or hear every idea Tom Petty considered for "Wildflowers."

Here are this year's best reissues and vault rediscoveries:
https://t.co/gXAs6AcAMh

name: NPR
text: EU legislators say negotiators have until midnight on Sunday to reach a post-Brexit agreement. Without one, next year could see trade choked off between the U.K. and the continent. https://t.co/svEoVcjpxO

name: NPR
text:
On this episode of @WorldCafe, NPR's pop critic, Ann Powers, brings you some of the best Nashville artists you might have missed this year.
https://t.co/wVZrdPqZw3

name: NPR
text: It's important to find joy in the midst of this dark winter, and carrying on with beloved traditions can help. Thankfully shopping, sugar plum fairies and Santa himself all are online this year, and there's lots of safe fun to be had outdoors. https://t.co/ATabaU1L5T

name: NPR
text: For many people, alcohol is a part of everyday life, but taking a break has its benefits. Experts offered @NPRLifeKit tips on how to do it -- and why.  https://t.co/edvEOWChjE

name: NPR
text: RT @pgogoi: Exclusive interview with top editor of @nytimes on why it is retracting the core of its award-winning podcast Caliphate and reassigning its star terrorism reporter @rcallimachi Hear @deanbaquet in his own words https://t.co/PSn3OEZoqf https://t.co/E3r6JodHHG

name: NPR
text:
When Dr. Joshua Barocas got the coronavirus vaccine, he was overwhelmed by emotions -- sorrow, gratitude, amazement and hope. 

This moment is like a marathon runner's final push to the finish, he writes: painful and difficult, but also inspiring. @WBUR https://t.co/8Urn96xWDj

name: NPR
text: Just In: Vice President Pence, Karen Pence, and Surgeon General Jerome Adams received a coronavirus vaccinations on… https://t.co/K4ICtRne3s

name: NPR
text:
RT @Roughly: Have you ever learned a new word from a language, only to be told by native speakers, “Oh, we don’t use that?”

That kept happening to producer @ngofeenm when he went to France.

And that series of French lessons led to a deeper discussion...about race.

https://t.co/msECIBH3FS

name: NPR
text: President-elect Joe Biden, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell all are expected t… https://t.co/NQbDD0pScH

name: NPR
text: Pence praised the FDA for its work evaluating the vaccines. He said he expects the agency to approve the Moderna vaccine later on Friday. https://t.co/NFC6JqancP

name: NPR
text: In an interview with Stephen Colbert, President-elect Biden said that he thinks the investigation into the taxes of his son, Hunter Biden, is "foul play" being "used to get to me." https://t.co/V71IUz2NjO

name: NPR
text:
The hottest decade on record is coming to a close, with the past five years being the hottest since 1880. The future will be even hotter. 

That will mean more years like 2020: increasingly powerful hurricanes, more intense wildfires, longer heat waves. https://t.co/YHQFPG16UG

name: NPR
text: Just in: The U.S. Supreme Court dodged a ruling on whether President Trump can exclude undocumented immigrants from a key census count. The opinion said the case was "riddled with contingencies and speculation that impede judicial review." https://t.co/hr7hNXtsZK

name: NPR
text:
Pfizer has at least 40 FDA-registered manufacturing facilities. Moderna has one. 

So how will Moderna make the 200 million doses it has contracted to provide the U.S. government by the end of June? 

A big part of the answer is outsourcing production.
https://t.co/KwdK2GcgXU

name: NPR
text: Gina McCarthy and John Kerry will lead the charge on President-elect Biden's ambitious climate goals. That means rejoining international efforts, like the Paris accords Kerry helped negotiate -- and taking tough steps in the U.S. to win back global trust. https://t.co/TkXFRHx3e2

name: NPR
text:
The New York Times has retracted "Caliphate" after an internal review found significant journalistic failings in the project's reporting. Host Rukmini Callimachi has been reassigned.
 
"We didn't listen hard enough to the evidence," Dean Baquet tells NPR. https://t.co/u84prqLo3e

name: NPR
text: RT @nprmusic: The @allsongs annual Listeners' Poll results are in! Did your favorites make the cut? https://t.co/xxi16x61ko https://t.co/r8IzdY0GkG

name: NPR
text: Much of Amazon's workforce in Europe is represented by unions, but the company so far has fought off labor organizing efforts in the United States. That could change soon, as workers at an Alabama warehouse move toward a unionization vote. https://t.co/WcViv9MvOv

name: NPR
text: The payload of rocks and debris that returned from the moon on China's lunar probe are the first brought back to Earth since 1976. They're also the youngest moon rocks collected, which could provide fresh insight for the global scientific community. https://t.co/tTctg94CMP

name: NPR
text:
Pushing back on HHS's claim that it's facing "production challenges," Pfizer says millions more vaccine doses are ready to go — once the government asks for them.

Meanwhile, some states say their allocations have been cut — which HHS calls "incorrect."
https://t.co/J9KG0rtk3D

name: NPR
text: RT @lesommer: 2020 was the year we basically ran out of adjectives for the many, many broken climate records. Right now, it's virtually tied for the hottest year on record.  Here are 4 ways it took a toll. https://t.co/IuLv5ZQXjZ

name: NPR
text: RT @NPRItsBeenAMin: Let's hear it, y'all. It's been a long, hard year, but what's the BEST THING that happened to you all year?

name: NPR
text: RT @wosunews: Ohio mayors and police chiefs from around the state have urged @GovMikeDeWine to veto “Stand Your Ground” if it reaches his desk. https://t.co/0WuTzEddsy

name: NPR
text: Science writer Robin Marantz knows a lot about emerging pathogens, but learned something new from her coronavirus diagnosis: Despite a spectacular scientific effort this past year, it's still a mystery how the coronavirus will behave inside any one of us. https://t.co/t8520TKk5t
